examples.title:
System
  settings list per‑feature toggles (Unlock iPhone, Apple Pay, Password
  AutoFill), “Reset Face ID,” and red Delete Face ID button
  requiring passcode.
examples.use_case:
Device
  unlocking and auth across apps.
examples.why_selected:
Shows
  granular enable/disable & data deletion for stored face templates.

examples.title:
“Face &
  Fingerprint Unlock” panel with “Delete face data,” slider for unlock only
  when eyes open, app‑revoke list.
examples.why_selected:
Adds
  liveness check toggle and per‑app scope—good least‑privilege model.

Explicit
  deletion control for sensitive biometric IDs, aligning with CCPA §1798.140.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Help
  users recognize, diagnose, recover; Error prevention

examples.title:
Settings ▸ Accounts ▸ Sign‑in options: Remove
  face/fingerprint, PIN fallback, and toggle “Enhanced anti‑spoofing.”
examples.why_selected:
Provides
  removal & anti‑spoofing enhancements with clear status icons.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Visibility
  of system status; User control & freedom

examples.title:
Single
  toggle: “Face recognition” ON/OFF; off deletes face template; explainer link.
examples.why_selected:
Simple
  global switch with deletion promise meets GDPR Art 17.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Aesthetic
  & minimalist design; Recognition rather than recall

examples.title:
Toggle
  for “Face grouping” with modal explaining local processing and how to clear
  face models; “Delete face models” action.
examples.why_selected:
Offers
  opt‑out and local erase aligning with data minimisation.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
User
  control & freedom; Match between system & real world

examples.title:

  warning; settings allow privacy‑zone reset and
  exclusion of boundary data from cloud.

Preventing
  accidental recording or collisions in VR.
examples.why_selected:
Classic
  spatial ring fence; visual/auditory prompts protect
  bystanders & property.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Visibility
  of system status; User control & freedom

  display shows coloured waveform when device records video; on‑device overlay
  “Recording” badge; bystanders see indicator.
examples.why_selected:
Hardware‑level
  indicator plus software badge fosters bystander privacy awareness.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Aesthetic
  & minimalist design; Recognition rather than recall

examples.company:
Microsoft
  HoloLens 2 - Spatial Mapping Consent Overlay
examples.title:
On start,
  overlay asks to allow environment data; link to “Spatial Data” settings with
  toggle to delete map.
examples.why_selected:
Direct
  consent + deletion capability for 3‑D scans aligning with GDPR minimisation.

examples.title:

  LEDs light up during photo/video; cannot be disabled; press‑and‑hold to force
  off.

Hardware
  indicator ensures notice to bystanders—regulatory focus area.

Privacy
  as default, Respect for user privacy

Error

examples.title:
Before AR
  mapping task, modal explains upload of video; user can opt‑out and still
  play.
examples.why_selected:
In‑context
  consent ensures optional sensitive data capture.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Match
  between system & real world; Flexibility & efficiency

examples.why_selected:
Example
  of granular multimodal permission in XR web context.

examples.title:
Settings ▸ Privacy & Security ▸ Analytics & Improvements explains that
  analytics use “differential privacy” and lists daily “learning cap
  resets”. Toggle defaults OFF in EU.
examples.why_selected:
Only
  mainstream mobile OS exposing the notion of a daily privacy budget to
  the lay user.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Recognition
  rather than recall; Error prevention
